The paper teaches reasoning models to think in a tiny symbolic language so they stay accurate while using far fewer tokens.

Standard reasoning models like DeepSeek R1 score well on math but write huge self talk, which makes inference slow and expensive.

To shrink this, the https://t.co/qm4iczd5z5

At 128K context, prefilling costs drop from ~$0.65 to ~$0.35 per million tokens. And Decoding drops from ~$2.4 to ~$0.8.

And the performance stays the same. On some long-context benchmarks, V3.2 actually scores higher.

Sparse attention isn‚Äôt new. But making it work without https://t.co/PxOcYMlEgU

3) DeepSeek Sparse Attention (DSA)

DeepSeek‚Äôs new V3.2 model introduces DeepSeek Sparse Attention (DSA), which brings complexity down from O(L¬≤) to O(Lk), where k is fixed.

How it works:

A lightweight Lightning Indexer scores which tokens actually matter for each query.

Small https://t.co/VsbLBEhmOL

@anshulkundaje Agreed. But the system is built to reward citations. Some institutions even require a baseline h index for promotion. System needs to change.
To be clear, I'm not critiquing the person posting this. Rather this obsession in the scientific community with citation counts as a measure of success.

When I partition the attention reduction into 1, 2, 4 and 16 chunks, the logits drift significantly, across all three dtypes.

I have fine-tuned over 100 different LLMs/VLMs for various use cases over the last 1‚Äì2 years, and here is my framework whenever I pick a new project or problem statement:

1. Benchmark/Evals Any problem you are solving for should have an evaluation set that you can easily

How to cold email instead: 

- a tacky but useful subject line: this application is gonna take you 30 seconds to read
- 3 bullet points crafted for the job you are asking for
- do not use ai
- get straight to the business, no bs no hope you are well https://t.co/vPf5h4mJ9q https://t.co/klmbjKn6bx
